fields.rendered_content:
A new version of KA Lite is out! You can update your current version, install a new one, or learn how to contribute on the development side.

It has been a busy summer here at FLE, and we are beyond ready to start sharing with all of you what we’ve been up to! Today, we are incredibly excited for the release of KA Lite version 0.10.0!

KA Lite provides many advantages other offline learning products may not: students can practice exercises, teachers can view coach reports, and all this data can be automatically shared across computers whenever an Internet connection is available. The feedback has been clear: people love these features, and want us to do even more to support their ability to flip the classroom. Here’s a peek at some of the new tools we’ve built to support you!

For everyone:

  • Way more documentation, including an expanded user manual on our wiki .

For teachers:

  • Extended coach reports - we now have three types of coach reports:
    • Tabular report for details on student performance on exercises or student engagement with videos, within a particular topic.
    • Scatter report to examine how student effort relates to their mastery.
    • Timeline report to view changes in mastery over time.
  • User usage reports - view login hours per student, on your local server.
  • Online coach reports - access data for any group or facility online, at http://kalite.learningequality.org.

For admins:

  • Better performance - we spent a lot of time optimizing performance for this release (e.g. with a robust caching system) while still delivering a completely cross-platform solution. We have also created installation instructions for efficient running on one of the cheapest deployment solution around: the $25 Raspberry Pi.
  • Synchronization reporting - before, you never knew if and when your server was syncing data. Now we provide these reports on your install and on our website, so you can verify that everything is working.
  • Central user usage reports - many of you need to report usage and mastery data to admins and funding sources. We’ve built an entirely new reporting system to summarize your data, viewable on each installation as well as centrally, through our website.
  • More robust subtitles support - we’ve heard your pain in downloading subtitles, and have revamped our system to make things more robust.
  • Detailed documentation - this has been added for configuration options and management of your system.

For students:

  • Student coach reports - when you log in, you’ll immediately see the progress you’ve made, with direct links to any materials that may have caused you trouble.
  • Video indicators - we now have colored links that let you know when videos exist as you navigate through topics.
  • More videos - it’s that simple - there are now more Khan Academy videos available in KA Lite to help you learn more!

While it took us months (and months!) to release this update, we’re already planning the next one. Look out for these exciting features in the weeks to come:

  • One-click installation and updates
  • Completely automated registration for fully streamlined data syncing
  • Language packs for a fully translated interface, with even faster subtitle downloads
  • Better viewing experience on tablets, and direct viewing from the Raspberry Pi!
  • Allowing students to import progress on Khan Academy’s website directly into KA Lite!
  • And always… more reporting, more videos, and more learning!

As always, minor issues or confusions with an update are possible. Take a look at our new documentation and FAQ,  or simply ping us at support@learningequality.org to help you get KA Lite up and running. In the meantime, stay tuned for stories about the incredible people using KA Lite and how we hope to continue supporting them.

fields.rendered_content:
"Not everyone can hop in a van and travel the Americas for a year. One family has, with KA Lite along for the ride.”

In February 2013, the budding FLE team received an email from a family who, in more than one way, is a little too cool for school. Jennifer, Witt and Quinn Sparks had written to inform the team that they'd decided to take a trip across the continental Americas, beginning in their home of Denver, Colorado, then driving all the way up to Inuvik, Northwest Territories, Canada, and then all the way down to Ushuaia, Argentina

Jennifer Sparks has been interested in education for several years and is a regular follower of several education-related online news sources. During the buildup to the trip, Jennifer went on a mission to find a source of educational materials for her 4-year-old son, Quinn, that they would be able to use on the road without a consistent Internet connection. She heard about KA Lite through Khan Academy's Facebook page and was immediately intrigued. After learning more about the project, the family was so excited about the potential for impact that they decided to help install KA Lite in offline communities that they will be visiting during their travels. Partnering with our team at FLE as well as the volunteer program Do Good as You Go, the Sparks have already installed KA Lite in two communities in Canada: the Napi Friendship Center in Pincher Creek, Alberta, Canada and the Inuvik Youth Centre in Inuvik, Northwest Territories, Canada

We highly recommend taking a good look at the Spark's blog which details their KA Lite installations, as well as their travels! If you're interested in learning more about the trip, visit the Sparks' Volunteering Page. Below is just a quick excerpt from their most recent installation, "Volunteering at the Inuvik Youth Center" to give you a taste:

"We got the software installed without too much trouble, and Doris started putting out the word that there was something new on the computer to see. In part, this involved shouting over to the kids riding in the nearby skate park. Quite convenient! The next afternoon we got about 8 boys into the center, aged from about 8 – 12. Jen put together a few short demonstrations of some of the Khan Academy videos, including one particularly pertinent about why the sun never sets in the summertime above the arctic circle!

To the extent that you can keep pre-teen boys’ attention with educational videos, the demonstrations went quite well. About a half an hour later it was the girls’ turn – the “Delta Girls” in particular, referring the Mackenzie River delta. We felt that the whole exercise turned out very well. Our hope is that we’ve made something available that will help a few people out, if and when they decide they need it."

You can continue tracking the Sparks’ progress on their personal site: whensparksfly.org. In the meantime, we are glad that so many are finding KA Lite to be useful. If you, like the Sparks Family, are having a good experience using our software, please email your story and pictures to stories@learningequality.org.

fields.rendered_content:
We are excited to announce that the Foundation of Learning Equality (FLE) was selected to participate in the privately funded, state-wide Khan in Idaho deployment! Khan in Idaho is a partnership between Khan Academy, Northern Nazarene University’s Center of Innovation in Teaching, and the state of Idaho to bring Khan Academy into 47 schools. Since September, Khan Academy content has been used as a central part of student curriculum in each of these schools. The Idaho Department of Corrections (IDOC) was among the educational institutions selected for the program, but for security reasons their learners are not permitted Internet access - a perfect use case for KA Lite!

The FLE has partnered with the IDOC, their administrative partners at the Corrections Corporation of America (CCA), and the NNU Center of Innovation in Teaching, to deploy Khan Academy learning resources to over 1,000 inmates through the installation of KA Lite in 7 Idaho prisons. This marks the largest deployment of KA Lite that we have actively supported to date. This partnership, which began with a joint teacher training session on June 18, launched KA Lite to IDOC inmates on September 3rd.

The FLE team sharing tips with IDOC educators during the September training sessions.

Even before the official release, we were already starting to see some exciting results: among inmates who piloted KA Lite at the Cottonwood facility, 20 of 20 students passed their math GEDs! This is unprecedented in IDOC classrooms, and teachers credited this newfound level of success to the use of KA Lite. There is a lot of enthusiasm from teachers that the self-paced, mastery-based learning that KA Lite offers will make a significant difference in the long-term outcome for these inmates.

Here at the FLE, we have been working to make KA Lite even better for this deployment. Many new features were designed and implemented to allow completely offline registration, ultimately aimed at allowing data-syncing via USB drives. When that is complete, data would be collected at each prison, then shared across all facilities without requiring any KA Lite installations to ever be online.

With this iteration, we also simplified the download and installation process by providing two simple download options and clickable scripts for launching a guided installation. There is still work to do before a public release of these features, but this is coming soon! Look out for KA Lite version 0.11 at the end of October, featuring:

  • One-click downloads and a guided installation process
  • Two-click setup for sharing data across installations
  • Tracking of student login hours
  • Exporting monthly summaries of student activity and progress

By participating in such a large project with partners such as KA, NNU, CCA, and the IDOC, we hope to establish an outstanding reputation that can help us find grants and other funding to support our mission. If you'd like to support our work and mission, contact us, or visit our our website to give today!

Long before the pilot program with the IDOC, KA Lite had already begun changing the lives of American inmates. Below is a guest post written by Edward J. Hills, an inmate at Clallam Bay Corrections Center in the far northwest corner of Washington state. We hope you find it as inspiring as we did.

Edward J. Hills is a KA Lite user and inmate at Clallam Bay Corrections Center.

Edward J. Hills - 5/6/2013

Khan Lite has rejuvenated my desire to earn my G.E.D.

I’m thirty eight years old and I dropped out of the fifth grade. The only other education I’ve received was when I came to prison. This is my third and last time returning to prison.

In prison, if a person doesn’t have his G.E.D., he is required to attend G.E.D. classes. Upon entering the classroom in prison, it was and usually is very difficult for me. I felt like since I was so far behind why bother. However, my instructor encouraged me to take some tests and we discovered with a little hard work and dedication I can achieve my G.E.D.

From left to right: student Brandon Olebar, instructor Thomas Hanley, and student Edward Hills around their KA Lite setup.

Brandon Olebar, a classmate of Edward Hill's, using KA Lite.

I like attending my G.E.D. class, because it provides me with a sense of what it was like when I attended regular school. The only difference is in prison you remain in your assigned classroom. When I first started my G.E.D. class, I was of course working out of text books. However, once Peninsula College implemented computers in the classroom and a program called Khan Academy Lite, it revolutionized the way I see education for myself. Khan has a multitude of tutorials (lessons and videos) and provides a map to follow for learning math concepts. Also, it allows me to earn points after completion of every lesson. Another thing I like about Khan Academy is that it allows me and my instructor to track my progress. But what I really like most about the Khan program is that it allows me and my classmates to work at our own pace. For example, if I get stuck working on fractions, I can take my time and review the exercises and videos until I get it right. This gives me time to comprehend math in a way that makes sense to me and helps me retain it.

Overall, returning to school in prison has been a wonderful experience. Most importantly, my instructors and the T.A’s have played a pivotal role on my journey to higher education.

Mr. Hills is a student of Corrections Education Director Brian Walsh from Peninsula College, a rural community college in Port Angeles, Washington. Mr. Walsh brings technology-enabled basic education and skills training to inmates at Clallam Bay Corrections Center, a 900-bed maximum security prison. There, he has installed KA Lite on 60 computers available to 250 students a day. They use KA Lite as a part of their training in GED test preparation, accounting, carpentry, business, and game development.

If you would like to find out more about ways KA Lite is changing the prison system or how you can join the efforts for an offline learning revolution, ping us at info@learningequality.org or start a post in our new FLE Forum.

fields.rendered_content:
We’ve got something new for you!

We recently launched a forum using the open-source Discourse platform. We believe that an open “virtual” social space will help us achieve our goals of developing a more human-centered educational model by facilitating communication between our users, friends, and supporters. We also believe that our forums might provide the user (that’s you!) with a faster response to questions than contacting us through email.

Easy to get started

First of all, our forum allows users to login with their existing social media accounts including Google, Facebook, Twitter and even Github.

Our login system allows you to use pre-existing social media accounts.

Once you login, you will see the following categories. Not only are these available, but we are happily adding and adjusting categories as we receive feedback from our community.

Many different forums are already created to make communicating easy. Can't find the one you want? Create your own!

Our Education category has discussion topics ranging across the fields of education, pedagogy, and learning models. This category serves as a perfect place to tell other educators how you use online/offline tools in your practice of teaching. As you see in the picture below, FLE members have already collected quite a few interesting resources about education and posted on the forum. How can you contribute to this community as well?

Each forum has subtopics to make topics easily searchable.

KA Lite: The Big Picture

What do you think about KA Lite so far? In our KA Lite: General category, community members can discuss anything related to KA Lite, such as

  • How are you using KA Lite?
  • What are your ideas for potential features?
  • What would you suggest to make KA Lite better?
People already use KA Lite many different ways across a variety of environments every day. What features in KA Lite do you like most? What do you want to see more in the future version? Add to this fantastic conversation on our forum about those topics with other end-users.

You Can Find Help Here!

We were always looking forward to building a community based support environment that lets KA Lite users help each other when they have issues. Although our organization members try our best to answer every technical question that crosses through our (plentiful!) inboxes, we are often busy with many other tasks it takes to make FLE better each day. Having a KA Lite Support category enables our users to search common issues, such as configuring, using, and installing KA Lite from old threads, as well as to receive support from other members on the forum.

KA Lite in Your Area

We have heard some of our deployment groups would like to reach out to other local groups that also use KA Lite in the same area, and we have listened to that feedback! Therefore, we opened the KA Lite Deployments category that facilitates local deployments connecting with one another.

Time to Learn

Our Tutorial category is for instructional posts that describe how to set up and work with KA Lite. We will post tutorial videos here periodically. If you made a tutorial for another deployment, feel free to share it in this category.

Time to get started!

Join the community and introduce yourself on the forum! Tell us how you found out about FLE and share your experience with KA Lite. We look forward to connecting with you there!

Our Tutorial category is for instructional posts that describe how to set up and work with KA Lite. We will post tutorial videos here periodically. If you made a tutorial for another deployment, feel free to share it in this category.

Time to get started!

Join the community and introduce yourself on the forum! Tell us how you found out about FLE and share your experience with KA Lite. We look forward to connecting with you there!

When our good friends at ISKME invited us to attend Big Ideas Fest, an event that they organize every December, we didn’t know what to expect, but we knew that it would be a blast and that we would meet a great group of people. Two of us from the Foundation for Learning Equality, Bethany and Jamie, were able to attend the 4 day event, which is held in picturesque Half Moon Bay (our pet theory is that ISKME organizes the event primarily for the purpose of making the rest of us jealous of their home turf).

What made Big Ideas Fest so unique was not just its message about collaboration but also the way in which it taught us this skill directly. A key component of the event is its “action collabs”: break-out groups that allow for about 20 strangers to work together in developing an innovative idea and prototyping it, towards the goal of revolutionizing education -- all in two days. The best part of this concept was that it allowed us the freedom to dream and to create without the confines of lecturers or even our chairs.

The speakers at BIF also taught us to be innovative in our approach to forming collaborations.  The students attending the conference from South San Francisco High School, through Roadtrip Nation, taught us the value of approaching people and asking them about their stories. Chris Emdin, co-creator of the #HipHopEd social media movement, talked about how he turned a lone idea into an international collaborative movement by simply going online and finding like-minded people, and always remaining “wide awake.”

We met many such wide awake people at BIF who were enthusiastic about innovation in education. One group we were really excited to hang out with was the teachers themselves, with whom we don’t normally have many opportunities to interact. For example, we had a great discussion with Todd Elkin, an arts educator, about his work bringing human needs, ingenuity, and diversity to the forefront of student awareness through shelter-building activities and dialogue between students in the SF Bay area and Bangalore, India. We also met the passionate people from KidMob, who literally mob schools to solve local community challenges through design education.

Alongside the organized conference events, there was tremendous value for us in the “meta-conference” -- such as hanging out with our friends from QFI, who always do a fantastic job of making sure the right people meet each other to spark exciting collaborations. We may have been clueless walking into BIF, but we left with a renewed sense of purpose and many, many new friends with whom we hope to collaborate

fields.rendered_content:
We recently sent Ben Cipollini, our Software Development Lead, to visit Rwanda’s first private medical school with a team from Stanford Medicine. Despite having provided software to many known (and even more unknown) deployments across the world, this was the first time FLE had traveled to deploy KA Lite in the field ourselves.

Below are excerpts from Ben's personal blog entry on the team’s travel and experience, as they reviewed the medical school’s curriculum and augmented it with digital learning materials from Stanford University and Khan Academy, along with comments relevant to the FLE and KA Lite deployment.

Why did I go?

[The] medical school opened three months ago; we’re here to understand, assess and help augment their efforts by installing digital learning materials the ISPG is unable to access online due to limited internet bandwidth.

This is a perfect situation to leverage all of KA Lite’s capabilities. With internet access, and with the requirement for students to log in, we’re able to see student usage patterns remotely from San Diego and Stanford University, yet at the same time allow students to use the video and exercise resources on the local network. Perfect.

Introductions

We stutter through thanks to all for hosting us, encourage the student body in their goal to gain more for their families through education, and try to describe what we’ve brought and how we think it can contribute to their goals. The bubbling, interruptive applause hints at the excitement the students, faculty, and administrators share with us in every subsequent interaction, with extra excitement reserved for Ami (who is a welcome neighbor, from Ghana) and the words Stanford University, whose brand recognition apparently reaches the rural hills of Rwanda.

Student assembly… for us. How’d they pull together that sound system in like, 15 minutes?! Photo credit: Jean Damascene Ntihinyuzwa/ISPG

A tip for others: if you travel to Africa as a guest to anybody, be prepared to present yourself at a moment’s notice! I really had to gather my thoughts quick, and try to explain in just a few simple english words what we were there to do.

As soon as the final applause clears, the pressure is on to deliver, and the three day countdown begins.

Because this was our first deployment in-person, I felt extra-responsible to deliver something that could easily be used after we were gone. That meant integrating content outside of Khan Academy into KA Lite--an extension of KA Lite that we’ve been hoping to do more generally for some time, and that we plan to call the Learning Exchange (LEX). Note: More about LEX to come in the months ahead; contact us if you’d like to help build it, or you’d like to use it!

On the Experience

For those who are not familiar, most software development experiences can be summed up as follows: sitting in a small room hour by hour, racing to develop features before whatever timeline is chasing me bites me in the ass from behind and devours me. Holed up in the ISPG’s IT server room, I felt right at home.

In my natural habitat, but thousands of miles away from home. Photo credit: Ami Kumordzie

As the software development lead for the FLE, I’ve put a lot of dev time in on KA Lite. Whether it’s in my living room at home, office at school, or the IT server room at the ISPG, it all feels like home when I get into programming. And we delivered!

We’re able to recover and deliver a co-branded, French-English bilingual system with a revamped administrative interface—all on a brand new, Internet-accessible server.

Behold: the first example of our co-delivered content, with KA Lite housing content from Khan Academy and Stanford Medicine videos.

This deployment of bilingual English-French content was our first (alpha) deployment of “internationalized” content, but keep your eyes out for more on this soon. We’re writing the software, but we’ll need your help doing the translations! Stay tuned for a blog entry on how you can help, or send us an email about your interest!

In the End...

we’re confident that what we’ve delivered will be useful… and used.

As always, this is the most important thing. With our remote tracking, we’ve seen 30 students create accounts so far, with more to come as students return from their holiday! You can read about my complete experience developing in Rwanda, but please, don’t hesitate to share your personal KA Lite deployments! Your stories about the usefulness of KA Lite are really important to us, and we’d love to hear your experiences.

Great things are on the horizon for digital education, and at the FLE we’re determined to help push things forward and make resources available to the entire world, not just the online world. Subscribe to our newsletter, follow us on Twitter, like us on Facebook, to hear our latest news and help support our efforts by sharing awareness with your friends!

We just want to start by saying the following effort would not have been possible without the support of two great organizations and all of our awesome donors! Thank you to the wonderful people at the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, the Qatar Foundation International, and all of our individual philanthropists for believing in us, our vision, and our software, and helping us take a shot at making education for all a reality!

Do you want KA Lite to ship with support for your language?

As of February 19, after dealing with some unanticipated challenges and many long nights of serious hacking by core developers Ben Cipollini and Aron Asor, KA Lite will support internationalization!

What exactly does this mean?

A sneak peek at the KA Lite homepage in Spanish!

First, the KA Lite user interface and Khan Academy exercises can now be translated into just about any language. Not only that, but we have built in support for dubbed videos, which means that now all of those high-quality dubbed videos sitting on the Khan Academy language channels can be incorporated right into a KA Lite installation!

We’re sure many of you volunteer translators, language advocates, and international deployment partners reading this right now are jumping out of your seats in long-awaited celebration, and we’re excited, too! But in some sense, the job is just beginning.

What languages will be supported?

We support the languages that you translate!

KA Lite has been installed in over 85 countries. Not only is that pretty awesome, but this also means that it needs to be able to run in the local language to maximize utility for learners.

We're proud that KA Lite has been installed all over the world!

Here is where you come in. We need your help to get the interface translated, so that these languages will be ready to ship with our platform! Our ability to support a language is completely dependent on the good will of translators like you.

Below is a table of current levels of language support.

LanguageKA Lite interface translations (of 593)Khan Academy translations (of 13616)Dubbed videos (of 4730)Subtitles (of 4730)Exercises translated?
Portuguese (pt-BR)20% (118)72% (9791)9439% (402)Yes
Danish (da)100% (593)80% (10932)7% (319)13% (634)Yes
French (fr)41% (241)49% (6655)5% (210)14% (653)Yes
Polish (pl)21% (126)44% (5960)15% (687)30% (1460)No
Spanish (es)28% (163)69% (9355)46% (2021)28% (1243)Yes

This next table are the languages that are not quite there yet, but stand a good chance of being officially supported soon once the translations increase.

LanguageKA Lite interface translations (of 593)Khan Academy translations (of 13616)Dubbed videos (of 4730)Subtitles (of 4730)Exercises translated?
Italian (it) 20% (116)3% (443)5% (247)12% (544)No
Greek (el)22% (122)10% (1368)5% (240)0%No
Japanese (ja)0%29% (3954)1% (79)0%No
Arabic (ar)21% (122)3% (383)10% (861)26% (1250)No
Bulgarian (bg)21% (122)29% (3948)2% (96)23% (1077)No
German (de)20% (116)48% (6546)7% (307)12% (573)No

How can you help?

Now that we have internationalization support, we need your help translating the interface and Khan exercises so that non-English speakers all over the world can have access to the platform in their language of choice. If you speak English and a second language, please join our volunteer translators corp by signing up for our translation volunteers mailing list, and please read our instructions for getting started submitting translations!

However, just because we’re releasing internationalization very soon doesn’t mean you have to be in a rush translating thousands of strings within the next few days -- we’ll be rebuilding the supported languages every two weeks to accommodate translations made after the release. So you can take your time to make sure the Khan Academy and KA Lite translations are top notch!

More comfortable in programming? We’ve got fun stuff for you as well! Read through the instructions for starting KA Lite development, and then browse through the list of issues on GitHub for something that suits your fancy. Feel free to join us in our public HipChat room for development discussion and don’t forget to subscribe to our developer mailing list as well.

Action items!

  • Sign up for our translator mailing list
  • Read more about how to help on our wiki page
  • Contact us with any questions at translations@learningequality.org

fields.rendered_content:
In our last blog post, we announced that today, we would be releasing a version of KA Lite that supported internationalization. We regret to inform you that due to a multitude of new, awesome features that will be coming along with the release of i18n, we’ve decided to delay the official release to mid-March. This will give us plenty of time to work through the known existing issues and fully test the entire platform to make sure it’s completely stable before you go off and install it in some of the most inaccessible computer labs in the world. We know it’s a bummer to have to wait a little longer, but can you imagine how grumpy you’d be with us if we told you it needed to be updated after you’d already done that?

We know that many of you are really looking forward to testing out the new wheels, so here’s the new game plan. This Friday, February 21, we’ll be releasing a beta version of KA Lite i18n. This basically means that if you follow our special instructions below, you can download a sneak-peek of KA Lite with i18n support. There’s just one catch: we know that there are bugs hiding in the code, and we need your help to report them to us.

How to get the beta

For your OS, follow the instructions for installing KA Lite. Note to windows users: follow the “Developer Instructions” from the bottom half of the Windows installation page--you cannot (yet) use the Windows Installer for getting i18n support. From the command prompt, within the ka-lite directory run git checkout release-0.11

That’s it! To install languages and have access to dubbed videos, visit the “Update” page within KA Lite.

What kind of bugs will I find?

Great question! There are really two types of bugs to expect in this release: software bugs and translation bugs.

Software Bugs

This is when you get a screen that you shouldn't. Just clicked a link that didn't take you anywhere? Software bug. Reach a page that says nothing, or just has a big "Error" sign with unintelligible techno-babble beneath it, sometimes in an unfriendly red color? Definitely a software bug. Trying to download things that aren't downloading? You guessed it. Software bug. But before we tell you how to report them, let's make sure it's not a translation bug

Translation Bugs

A translation bug is a much less serious problem, but definitely still something we need you to report. Did you download a language pack, switch into that language, and nothing happened? Translation bug. Did you switch into your language successfully, and then notice the whole navigation bar is still in English? Translation bug. If you find a translation bug, please don't report it to us through GitHub. Instead, just email a description of what happened, with a screenshot, to i18n@learningequality.org. If you're sure it's a software bug, please read on to learn how to report them.

How you can help us report software bugs

We use GitHub to log our issues. If you’re unfamiliar, GitHub is a really helpful tool for developers that lets us host our source code online and collaborate as we make changes to it. Anyway, if you find a bug, or something that doesn't seem to be working right in the beta version you download, here's how you can report it. If you don’t have one yet, please make a GitHub account.

Steps to report bugs:

  1. Visit https://github.com/learningequality/ka-lite/issues
  2. Click the green “New Issue” button in the upper-right corner of the web page.
  3. Put a good, clear title in the “Title” box
    • a good title will be descriptive and specific like: “404 not found on Device Management page” vs a bad title like: “page doesn’t work”
  4. In the comment box, be sure to include the following:
    • A screenshot of the entire page where you found the bug
    • The exact steps it would take to make the bug happen again. For example: “First I clicked ‘Watch’ in the navigation bar, and then KA Lite just exploded!”
    • Your operating system and browser. For example: “Windows 7, Chrome”

Click here for an example of an issue with ample description and screenshots.

tl;dr

  1. stable release of i18n has been delayed from 2/19 to mid-March
  2. We’re releasing the beta on Friday
  3. Instructions on how to get it above
  4. Please, please help us find bugs and report them! Instructions above

If you find a translation bug, please don't report it to us through GitHub. Instead, just email a description of what happened, with a screenshot, to i18n@learningequality.org. If you're sure it's a software bug, please read on to learn how to report them.

How you can help us report software bugs

We use GitHub to log our issues. If you’re unfamiliar, GitHub is a really helpful tool for developers that lets us host our source code online and collaborate as we make changes to it. Anyway, if you find a bug, or something that doesn't seem to be working right in the beta version you download, here's how you can report it. If you don’t have one yet, please make a GitHub account.

Steps to report bugs:

  1. Visit https://github.com/learningequality/ka-lite/issues
  2. Click the green “New Issue” button in the upper-right corner of the web page.
  3. Put a good, clear title in the “Title” box
    • a good title will be descriptive and specific like: “404 not found on Device Management page” vs a bad title like: “page doesn’t work”
  4. In the comment box, be sure to include the following:
    • A screenshot of the entire page where you found the bug
    • The exact steps it would take to make the bug happen again. For example: “First I clicked ‘Watch’ in the navigation bar, and then KA Lite just exploded!”
    • Your operating system and browser. For example: “Windows 7, Chrome”

Click here for an example of an issue with ample description and screenshots.

tl;dr

  1. stable release of i18n has been delayed from 2/19 to mid-March
  2. We’re releasing the beta on Friday
  3. Instructions on how to get it above
  4. Please, please help us find bugs and report them! Instructions above

After 5 months, over 700 commits and 230 closed issues, the Foundation for Learning Equality is proud to present you: release 0.11.1, with internationalization support! This release brings i18n support full-circle, along with a slew of goodies, bugfixes and performance improvements.

Interface translations

One of the first things that you will notice is the language selection box in the upper right:

The KA Lite homepage featuring a new language switching bar!

If you have a fresh install then you can only select English for now. If you’re an admin, head on over to the Update > Manage Language Packs page which will allow you to download any of the currently supported languages:

Download or update your language packs on the Update page

Once you’ve downloaded the language, you can set it as the server default, or just leave it as an option for your users to select -- each user can select whichever language works best for them. Once selected, you will be greeted by an interface translated into that language:

KA Lite... in German!

Dubbed videos and subtitles

You can also download dubbed videos if they are available for your selected language. Just go to the Update Videos page, and select the language in which to download videos:

You can download dubbed videos if they are available

Subtitles are working great as well!

Subtitles work great

Exercises

Translated exercises are also available for select languages:

And exercises are translated too!

Supported languages

We would love to support each and every language out there, however not all languages have been sufficiently translated. fields.rendered_content:
With limited resources and only nine coaches, a group from Taylor University made its way to Butaw, Liberia, in partnership with the Golden Veroleum Liberia Elementary School. For this deployment, the goal was to have a four day mathematics workshop for the students in order to examine the effectiveness of KA Lite in rural Liberian schools.

Sixteen teachers from the Golden Veroleum Liberia Elementary School and four Greenville high schools spent the first day learning to use the computer and how KA Lite worked, and then picking out 16 students from each of the 5th, 6th, 9th, and 12th grades. Over the following 3 days, each of these students participated in six sessions of about an hour to an hour and a half in length, twice each day.

One student beams at the camera as she starts using the laptop.

There were sixteen laptops set up in two different classrooms, with students paired and matched to computers based on their basic math abilities, determined by pre-testing before the program began. Unsurprisingly, their scores were overall extremely low, representative of the challenges facing post-war rural Liberia’s educational system.

To begin using KA Lite, the students first had to learn to familiarize themselves with the computers, as many had never seen or used a computer before. In order to learn how to use the mouse, the keyboard, and other basic functions of the computer, students worked together and used a variety of instructional programs. The initial teamwork and collaboration showed that the students were collectively engaged in the learning process, and willing to help one another as they embarked on this unforgettable learning opportunity.

Students were all smiles as they learned to navigate laptops for the first time.

Students were given a “Samuel Morris Scholars Program” t-shirt that all of them wore enthusiastically for the remainder of the program, and that will serve as a physical reminder of this unique experience. Samuel Morris was a young Liberian, son of a Kru tribal chief who, in 1891, found his way to the United States and Taylor University, and dramatically impacted the future of the University.

Students wearing their Samuel Morris shirts while working through their math lessons.

By the second day of instruction, the children had learned to login to the program and were eagerly getting to work. They watched videos, mastered exercise sets, and spent time collaborating on ideas and solutions to the problems they encountered. Once again, this cooperation proved that this was not an individual journey for each student, but instead a collective effort to help each other, and ultimately, help themselves.

Students shared laptops, which encouraged collaborative learning and cooperation.

At the end of the third day of instruction, the students were given a post-test to reveal their progress after using KA Lite for three consecutive days to learn mathematics. Students’ scores improved by an unexpectedly high average of 29%! In simply eight hours of total class time, the children not only learned how to navigate Windows and operate KA Lite, but they also showed marked improvements in their math skills.

On the final day of the deployment, the students received “Samuel Morris Scholar” certificates, validating all of the hard work they had poured into this program. Their progress was undeniable, and served as a lasting memory for all of those involved.

On the final day, all students gathered to receive certificates signifying their hard work and accomplishments!

Based on the success of the inaugural Samuel Morris Scholars Program, the group from Taylor University has plans for a second deployment in Butaw, Liberia next January, with another set of coaches. The goal for this deployment will be to check up on the students and to conduct some follow-up sessions with the schools. In the meantime, FLE continues to support deployments like these around the world, and we are hoping to share more stories over the coming months. Can’t wait? Then visit our forums now and have the chance to connect with other KA Lite deployers! If you have a story to share, we'd love to hear it! Contact us at stories@learningequality.org
